about.title: Who We Are
about.description: The Kichwa Karanki indigenous people are an ancient culture inhabiting Northern Ecuador, specifically in Imbabura province. Descendants of the lordships of Caranqui, Cayambe and Otavalo, we keep our identity alive through traditional agricultural practices, ancestral festivities and a worldview deeply connected with Pacha Mama (Mother Earth).

location.ibarra: Ibarra: La Esperanza, Angochagua, Caranqui, San Antonio
location.pimampiro: Pimampiro: Mariano Acosta, San Francisco de Sigsipamba

culture.title: Material Culture
culture.subtitle: Our people's identity expressed in every garment and craft

men.title: Men's Clothing
men.description: Karanki men wear white pants and white shirt, accompanied by a red wool poncho for special celebrations and a blue one for daily use. They complete their attire with white espadrilles and a short-brimmed hat.

women.title: Women's Clothing
women.description: Women wear a multicolor embroidered white blouse that reaches a quarter below the knee. They cover themselves with a blue or black anaco (skirt) tied at the waist with colored sashes. They adorn their necks with walka (golden necklaces) and their wrists with manilas (red coral bracelets). They complete the outfit with a black hat, black espadrilles and a brightly colored shawl.

language.title: Kichwa Language
language.subtitle: The voice of our ancestors
language.description: Kichwa is the official language among the Karanki people, while Spanish is considered the second language. Originally, the Karanki would have spoken a Barbacoan family language, which was replaced by Kichwa during the Inca expansion.
language.statusDescription: Currently we face challenges such as negative attitudes towards Kichwa and lack of coherent public policies for its promotion.
language.revitalizationDescription: We implement the Bilingual Intercultural Education Model (MOSEIB) to preserve cultural identity and strengthen students' linguistic competence in Kichwa.

embroidery.title: Hand Embroidery
embroidery.description: Hand embroidery has traditionally been an important craft. Shirts are very diverse and colorful, using various colored threads on a piece of drawn white fabric where embroidery is meticulously done. Karanki women's embroidery has transcended the country's borders, participating in national and international fairs.

beadwork.title: Bead Work
beadwork.description: Elderly people preserve the art of collecting tiny red mullos (beads) on thread to make bracelets that older women wear.

tablecloths.title: Tablecloth Embroidery
tablecloths.description: Tablecloth embroidery is made using wool threads of different colors, polyester fabric, lace, canvas fabrics, needles and round vellum molds.

organization.title: Organizational Structure
organization.subtitle: Democratic governance rooted in ancestral wisdom

cabildo.title: Council of Cabildo
cabildo.description: Each year, the Council of Cabildo prepares a plan and submits it to the Assembly for approval. Activities are planned in general assemblies, where decisions for community development are made.
cabildo.roles: President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Syndic

elders.title: Council of Elders
elders.description: There is a Council of Elders whose function is to help with their wisdom to solve matters related to theft, gangs, land conflicts, neighborhood feuds or gossip.

women.title: Women's Role
women.description: Women are in charge of transmitting knowledge practically through couplets and dances.

minga.title: The Minga
minga.description: Minga (minkay) is a cultural activity where both community members and the cabildo dedicate time and effort for the common good: improving street and path conditions, helping maintain the communal house or institutions. Minga is a fusion of collective work and community celebration.
minga.activities: Road repair, maintenance of public spaces, house construction, agricultural harvests

economy.title: Community Economy
economy.subtitle: Sustainable production in harmony with nature

agriculture.title: Agriculture
agriculture.description: The main activity is agricultural. In the hills and high places they cultivate cold climate products: wheat, barley, potatoes, ocas; in the lowlands they cultivate corn to sell in cities.

livestock.title: Livestock
livestock.description: Some families raise cows and sheep, selling milk and wool for income.

tourism.title: Community Tourism
tourism.description: Some communities have developed community tourism projects offering cultural experiences and connection with nature.
tourism.example: Community of La Magdalena - tourism and crafts

barter.title: Barter System
barter.description: The traditional barter system (trueque) is still practiced, exchanging agricultural and livestock products between communities and regions.

traditions.title: Ancestral Traditions
traditions.subtitle: Celebrations that connect us with the cosmos and Pacha Mama

festivals.title: Main Festivals
festivals.subtitle: The ceremonial calendar marks our connection with cosmic cycles

inti.name: Inti Raymi
inti.description: The Festival of the Sun (Inti Raymi) celebrates the summer solstice and agricultural harvest. It is the most important celebration, where gratitude is expressed to Inti Taita (Father Sun) for crops and life.
inti.locations: San Juan de Ilumán, Angochagua, La Esperanza, Caranqui

kulla.name: Kulla Raymi
kulla.description: The Festival of the Woman and Femininity, celebrated during the equinox. Honors feminine strength and the role of women in community and Andean cosmovision.

pawkar.name: Paukar Raymi
pawkar.description: Festival of Flowering, celebrated at the spring equinox. Marks the beginning of agricultural season and nature's renewal.

inti.title: Inti Raymi Ritual
inti.description: Offerings and ceremonies to Father Sun, including sacred baths and thanks for the harvest.

pachamanca.title: Pachamanca
pachamanca.description: Ceremonial cooking in earth pits, where food is offered to Pacha Mama before sharing among the community.

baston.title: Staff of Command
baston.description: Ceremony of power transfer where new authorities receive the staff symbolizing their responsibility to the community.

marriage.title: Karanki Marriage
marriage.description: The gashto (formal request), sirvicha (service period) and wedding constitute the marriage process. It is a community event where both families unite.
marriage.sirvicha: Period where the groom demonstrates his worth by serving the bride's family

wasi.title: Wasi Pichay
wasi.description: House cleaning ceremony, where the community gathers to purify and bless a new home or renew an old one.

music.title: Music and Dance
music.subtitle: Rhythms that connect us with our ancestors

instruments.title: Traditional Instruments
instruments.description: The Karanki people play traditional instruments to perform sanjuanitos and other traditional music. Folkloric accompaniment is used in marriage celebrations.

contemporary.title: Contemporary Groups
contemporary.description: New generations keep music alive through groups fusing traditional rhythms with modern styles.
contemporary.kipiku: Group Kipiku - Fusion of ancestral and contemporary music

dance.title: Traditional Dances
dance.description: The San Juan is the most representative dance, performed in circles around bonfires during Inti Raymi. Other dances include the yumbo and danzante, performed with colorful costumes and masks.

cosmovision.title: Andean Worldview
cosmovision.subtitle: Our relationship with the cosmos and Pacha Mama

pachaMama.title: Pacha Mama
pachaMama.description: Mother Earth is the center of Karanki cosmovision. She provides life, food and shelter. The relationship with her is one of respect, reciprocity and gratitude.

astral.title: Astral Signs
astral.moon: The moon influences planting and harvests
astral.rainbow: The rainbow brings rain and fertility

animals.title: Animal Signs
animals.condor: The condor is a sacred messenger

midwife.title: Traditional Midwifery
midwife.description: Midwives accompany women during pregnancy and childbirth using ancestral techniques and medicinal plants.

limpia.title: Spiritual Cleansing
limpia.description: Ritual cleansing with medicinal plants, eggs and other elements to remove negative energies.

espanto.title: Fright Healing
espanto.description: Healing ritual for fright or soul loss, using prayers, herbs and spiritual baths.

gallery.title: Photo Gallery
gallery.subtitle: Images of our culture and daily life

contact.subtitle: We'd love to hear from you

q1.question: Can I visit Karanki communities?
q1.answer: Yes, some communities offer community tourism. We recommend contacting local tourism offices in Otavalo or Ibarra to coordinate respectful cultural visits.

q2.question: When is Inti Raymi celebrated?
q2.answer: Inti Raymi is celebrated around June 21, the summer solstice. Celebrations extend for several days with dances, rituals and community gatherings in various communities.

q3.question: Where can I purchase Karanki handicrafts?
q3.answer: You can find our embroidery and handicrafts at Otavalo's indigenous market, the largest artisan market in South America, open every day with its peak on Saturdays.

q4.question: Is Kichwa still spoken in communities?
q4.answer: Yes, Kichwa is still spoken especially among older people. There are revitalization efforts through bilingual education (MOSEIB) to strengthen the language among new generations.
